an4.76:1: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Kusinārāā between the twin sal trees in the sal-tree grove of the Mallas at Upavattana, on the occasion of his final nibbāna. There the Blessed One addressed the bhikkhus: "Bhikkhus!"
an4.76:2: "Bhikkhus, it may be that even a single bhikkhu has some doubt or uncertainty about the Buddha, the Dhamma, or the Saṅgha, about the path or the practice.[n.770] What occurs from this point on is also in the Mahāparinibbāna Sutta,DN 16.6.5, II 154–55.Then ask, bhikkhus. Do not be remorseful later, thinking: ‘Our teacher was present before us, yet we could not bring ourselves to question the Blessed One when we were in his presence.’
an4.76:3-4: A second time … A third time the Blessed One addressed the bhikkhus … And a third time the bhikkhus were silent.
an4.76:5: Then the Blessed One addressed the bhikkhus: "It may be the case, bhikkhus, that you do not ask out of respect for the teacher. Then report your questions to a friend." When this was said, the bhikkhus were still silent.
an4.76:6: "You speak out of confidence, Ānanda, but the Tathāgata knows this for a fact. For among these five hundred bhikkhus, even the least is a stream-enterer, no longer subject torebirth inthe lower world, fixed in destiny, heading for enlightenment."
